g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Increased bioenergy consumption is considered in many 1.5˚C and 2˚C scenarios. System thinking is
needed to evaluate bioenergy’s viability because increased demand could affect land and water
nexus, policies and models must consider interconne
sectors, which is currently not the norm
A systems approach is also needed to support technological innovation. This includes recogni
unintended consequences of political support mechanisms
sector benefits. It also entails assimilating knowledge from multiple
sources as a basis for policy and decision
Current literature does not explicitly consider systematic, physical drivers of inertia, such as capital and
infrastructure needed to support accelerated mitigation
understand what is needed to successfully shift from current limited mitigation actions to significant
transformations needed to rapidly achieve deep mitigation.
Implications of accelerated mitigation for national development objectives
This section examines how accelerated mitigation may impact the realisation of development objectives
term. It focuses on three objectives discussed in the literature, sustaining economic
), and alleviating poverty and ensuring equity (
It complements similar review performed at global level in section 3.6. For a comprehensive survey of
research on the impact of mitigation in other areas (including air quality, health, and
Mitigation and economic growth in the near
A significant part of the literature assesses the impacts of mitigation on GDP, consistent with
It must be noted upfront that
on which our assessments are mostly based, capture the impact of mitigation on GDP and other core
economic variables while typically overlooking other effects that may matter (like improvements in air
quality). Second, even though GDP (or better, G
DP per capita) is not an indicator of welfare
ges in welfare indicators in the areas of poverty, health, and education
The mechanisms linking mitigation to GDP outlined below would remain valid even with alternative
growth as a goal, instead advocating a range of alternatives
approaches to achieve rapid mitigation while improving social outcomes
language of the present chapter, these alternatives constitute alternative development path
igation modelling studies in which GDP is an endogenous variable report
negative impacts of mitigation on GDP in 2030 and 2050, relative to the reference (
2018a; Cui et al. 2019; Zhao et al. 2018; Li et al. 2017; Dong et al. 2018; Dai et al. 2016)

relationship between mitigation effort and emissions is strong in studies up to 2030, much weaker for
